title: United Airlines, Procter & Gamble, Moderna: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week's news. America's vacation from travel restrictions might get cancelled. The European Union recommended halting nonessential travel from the U.S. because of the rise of Covid-19 cases, diplomats said Monday. The bloc's earlier decision, in June, to place the U.S. on its safe list was a welcome relief for Europe's tourist-heavy southern economies after pandemic-fueled recessions. The trade group Airlines for America called the recommendations a disappointment to the U.S. airline industry. United Airlines shares lost 3.8% Monday.

title: The Covid Booster Debate
summary: The case is strong for a third shot, never mind the political motives.. Covid vaccines can make for strange bedfellows, and raise your hand if you thought the Biden White House would be accused of ignoring the science? We didn't think so. But that's been the charge as two Food and Drug Administration regulators have resigned amid what media leaks claim is too much political agitation for Covid vaccine booster shots.

title: The Biden Jobs Paradox
summary: Job participation is stagnant, though employers need workers.. The jobs report for August was a major disappointment, and it underscores the paradox of the labor market during the Biden Administration: Employers are desperate for workers and paying them more, but too few workers are coming off the sidelines to take available jobs.

title: Where Your Taxes Went This Summer
summary: The vital duties the feds performed last month run to 7,492 pages.. Summer is for the beach, but the regulatory state never takes a holiday. In August alone, 7,492 pages were added to the Federal Register, recording every twitch of the administrative giant. So what did the feds do instead of lazing in the sun? We didn't read it all (we're journalists, not masochists), but here's a light sample from the first week of last month:

title: Biden's Dream of an IRS Strike Team
summary: He says more tax audits can recover $700 billion. Not even close.. When President Biden talks of bulking up the Internal Revenue Service, he must be fantasizing about some kind of SEAL Team 6 for audits. His plan is to put another $80 billion into IRS tax enforcement over 10 years, which the White House claims will raise $700 billion of revenue that's being left on the table.

title: Notable & Quotable: High Culture, Not High Demand

title: Homelessness Is Behind the Anger at Gavin Newsom
summary: Tent cities, street chaos and public disorder have spread to every corner of California under his watch.. If California voters recall Gov. Gavin Newsom on Sept. 14, homelessness will be a big part of the reason. According to statistics from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, homelessness in California rose 40% over the past five years. Though only 12% of the U.S. population lives in California, the Golden State hosts half of the nation's street population. Certain neighborhoods, such as Los Angeles's Skid Row, have been notorious for decades. Mr. Newsom's problem is that under his watch, homelessness has spread to every corner of the state.

title: Media Can't Handle the Climate Truth

title: 'Invention' Review: James Dyson's Dilemma
summary: Building a better vacuum cleaner is just the start. An inventor must also find funding, distribution and, most crucially, trained engineers.. James Dyson was a less than stellar student at the boarding school he attended in Norfolk, England, where his father was a classics master. Yet he would become the founder of a family-owned global manufacturing empire. Mr. Dyson gained fame-and a peerage-as the inventor of a revolutionary vacuum cleaner that exploits the principle of the cyclone and never needs a replacement bag, among other novel domestic appliances. But even this achievement was hardly to be expected from the early trajectory of his life.

title: 'Cuba: An American History' Review: That Infernal Little Republic
summary: Cuba has spent its entire existence as a state and much of its late colonial past in Uncle Sam's purported backyard.. When Barack Obama met Raúl Castro, in an attempt to re-forge friendship, he stressed continuities that bind Cuba and the U.S. His claim that the same ideals inspired both can probably be dismissed as rhetoric. He surely spoke from the heart, however, when he averred, with only a little exaggeration, that "like the United States the Cuban people can trace their heritage both to slaves and slave-owners."

title: 'Into the Forest' Review: Evading the Hounds of Hell

And the hybrid state of working from home and popping by the office, referred to by managers as "flex," is, for many, the new full-time.

After all, I was saving the Earth.

title: Will New York Come Back? Will New Yorkers?
summary: The likely next mayor says he'll lobby all those exiles in Florida to come back, and explains how he'll reduce crime while restoring trust in police.. "On Jan. 2, 2022," he says, "I'm taking a flight to Florida, and I'm telling all those New Yorkers that live in Florida-I'm telling them, 'Bring your butt back to New York.' "

title: Colleges Violate Their Promises to Vaccinated Students
summary: Students who got the shots to help others are ordered to wear masks outside and stay out of restaurants.. Colleges these days aspire to inculcate ethics and morals as well as knowledge. Yet many of them have gone all in on deceiving and gaslighting students by violating the bargain-both implied and explicitly stated-agreed to this summer when they mandated vaccination against Covid-19: You get vaccinated to protect the rest of us, and we give you your lives back.

title: Botticelli the Businessman
summary: A new exhibition shows how the Renaissance master created 'a production line of images' for the art market. Sandro Botticelli's reputation as an artist of extraordinary refinement tends to overshadow his skill as an entrepreneur. Giorgio Vasari, the pre-eminent chronicler of the Italian Renaissance, wrote that Botticelli (1445-1510) "squandered his money" and died in Florence a penniless old man. Yet a very different portrait of a savvy businessman emerges in "Botticelli: Artist and Designer," a new exhibition opening Sept. 10 at the Musée Jacquemart-André in Paris.

title: The IRS's 11 Million 'Math Error' Notices
summary: Tax changes like the ones brought by last year's stimulus payments often trigger a surge in such problems. Millions of Americans have gotten a scary, confusing letter from the Internal Revenue Service in 2021 saying they owe more taxes. Making matters worse, many of the letters are about stimulus payments meant to lessen the blow of the pandemic.

title: Samantha Cristoforetti Is Heading Back to Space
summary: After publishing a memoir, the Italian astronaut will return to the International Space Station next year as its commander. Samantha Cristoforetti doesn't remember exactly when she decided to become an astronaut. "At some point, I just knew," she says. In Malè, the small village in the Italian Alps where she grew up, "there weren't a lot of scientists or engineers, or astronauts for sure." But as she writes in her memoir "Diary of an Apprentice Astronaut," published in the U.S. this week, Ms. Cristoforetti remains a devoted fan of the books and TV shows that introduced her to space travel, such as "Star Trek" and "The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy." In a village with scant light pollution, she often felt like she could touch the stars.

title: Apple Delays Update That Could Scan iPhone for Illegal Content
summary: Tech giant says it will take more time to collect input and make improvements before releasing feature. Apple Inc. is delaying the rollout of tools aimed at combating child pornography on iPhones after sparking concern among privacy advocates that the software could create broader risks for users.

title: Poppy Seed Recipes: Sprinkle on Some Glamour
summary: This ingredient confers more than crunch and subtle smoky flavor: Poppy seeds give familiar dishes a dash of intrigue. Try them in pastas, porridges, vinaigrettes and these recipes for a nutty buckwheat shortbread and a warm leek-tomato salad.. I'M GUESSING the most pressing question many readers will bring to this article pertains to drug testing. And the answer is yes, you might fail a drug test (depending on the test) if you have eaten, say, a poppy seed bagel within 48 hours-though the seeds won't get you high.

summary: Bill Clinton missed his shot at Osama bin Laden, too.. Fair enough, but a series of catastrophic missteps have been occurring in real time at the Kabul airport

summary: Delta variant weighed on U.S. labor market last month; for this month, expect more of the same. Covid-19 hit America's job market last month. The question is how much of that was because employers were less willing to hire and how much of it was because it cut into would-be employees' willingness to find work.

title: The Other Pandemic: Stupidity
summary: A few additions to Lance Morrow's list.. In "You Are Living in the Golden Age of Stupidity" (op-ed, Aug. 30), Lance Morrow notes, "You will have your own list, of course." I accept his invitation and suggest a few additions:

title: The Conservationist Case Against Watering Your Lawn
summary: Switch to xeriscaping. The environment will thank you.. The excellent article "Uncommon Lawns" (Off Duty, Aug. 28) merits a follow-up on water-conservation landscaping. Lawns consume a lot of water. My over-55 community has only xeriscape yards with drip systems for trees, shrubs and flowers. The backyards of the community are large patios with garden areas for flowers, vegetables and herbs. My mountain community didn't permit lawns to compete for water with snow-making use.

title: Five Best: On Resistance
summary: Selected by Jennifer Chiaverini, the author, most recently, of the novel 'The Women's March.'. By Judy Batalion (2020)

title: Why One College President Was Grateful for New Jersey
summary: Penn State's leader faced east and thanked God for out-of-state tuition.. Aaron Klein's op-ed "Public Colleges Reach Across State Lines for a Tuition Windfall" (Aug. 31) brings back memories of the aughts, when the Pennsylvania legislature continued cutting its allocation to Penn State University while demanding that tuition remain affordable for Pennsylvania residents.

title: How Many Intelligence Agencies Does It Take to Investigate Wuhan?
summary: There has to be monumental overlap.. "The Covid Origin Muddle" (Review & Outlook, Aug. 28) mentions that the U.S. has 18 intelligence agencies. What? There has to be monumental overlap and a glut of wasted taxpayer dollars. How can this be? Oh, yes: "I'm from the government and I'm here to help."

title: Science Fiction: Max Barry's 'The 22 Murders of Madison May' Review
summary: A rejected fan hunts an actress through various worlds to find one where she will love him in return. Every time he fails, he kills her.. The multiverse is a familiar trope in science fiction, given life by our uncertainty about Schrödinger's cat and quantum physics. Is it possible that there are many worlds, parallel to ours, constantly folding and splitting off, so that we have innumerable duplicates of ourselves, all of them slightly different?

title: Book Review: Colson Whitehead's 'Harlem Shuffle'
summary: A warm, involving novel that reveals gradual changes in Harlem, in New York City, and in the protagonist himself.. For some African-American writers, New York's uptown neighborhood of Harlem represents both a crucible and a showcase. Writing about Harlem has been known to launch literary careers, for those good enough to capture something of the vibrancy and rich history, the majesty and appalling poverty, the sounds, smells and feel of the place-its growth in the early 20th century into the capital of Black America, with the nation's largest concentration of African-Americans; the birth, in the 1920s, of the Harlem Renaissance, an explosive movement of literature, art and music; the continued tough economic times and resulting crime; the quiet majority of citizens who work hard in the daytime and return to their families in the evening. But how to evoke, in the words of Ann Petry, this "hodgepodge of churches, bars, beauty parlors [and] harsh orange-red neon signs," this lush urban world "as varied and as full of ambivalences as Manhattan itself"? Many writers have taken up the challenge. The Jamaican-born Claude McKay published the novel "Home to Harlem" in 1928, and the action in Nella Larsen's 1929 classic "Passing" takes place in Harlem. Ralph Ellison set part of his groundbreaking 1952 novel "Invisible Man" there; Chester Himes chose the neighborhood as the backdrop for a series of slim, zany, biting, frequently hilarious crime novels featuring the detectives Grave Digger Jones and Coffin Ed Johnson, among them "Cotton Comes to Harlem" (1965). Unlike all of those writers, James Baldwin grew up in Harlem and-for all the time he spent abroad-in some ways never left, writing about his birthplace in essays such as the immortal "Notes of a Native Son" and in fiction including his first novel, "Go Tell It on the Mountain" (1953). Works by contemporary writers include Sharifa Rhodes-Pitts's 2011 nonfiction book "Harlem Is Nowhere," whose title is taken from an Ellison essay. And now comes Colson Whitehead's new novel, "Harlem Shuffle."

title: Fiction: Reviews of 'Beautiful World, Where Are You' and 'The War for Gloria'
summary: Sally Rooney's new novel features an Irish writer whose bestsellers are lauded and then mocked, causing her to retreat to the countryside.. A little ignorance can be useful when trying to see a novel plain, especially when a book is freighted with as much autobiographical melodrama as Sally Rooney's "Beautiful World, Where Are You". Ms. Rooney is the author of hugely popular novels about the love lives of Irish millenials, "Conversations With Friends" and "Normal People," for which she was lauded, and subsequently mocked, as the voice of her generation. Her newest book centers on a novelist whose bestsellers were similarly lauded and mocked, causing her to suffer a nervous breakdown and retreat to the Irish countryside, where she writes caustic letters to her best friend about the "disfiguring social disease" of celebrity worship. Viewed in the context of Ms. Rooney's now-public private life, the book can be taken as something entirely distinct from literature-as simply the latest volley in the rancorous back-and-forth that is known, on the internet, as Discourse.

title: 'Windswept' Review: The Way She Moves
summary: Georgia O'Keeffe found inspiration for her paintings as she walked through the New Mexico desert. Simone de Beauvoir reveled in both urban strolls and rugged hikes-undertaken in espadrilles.. In his "Confessions," Jean-Jacques Rousseau wrote that walking fueled his thoughts, and that when he stopped walking, he stopped thinking: "My mind only works with my legs." Friedrich Nietzsche believed that "only thoughts which come from walking have any value." Other men who have extolled the cerebral, emotional and physical benefits of walking-in what the English nature writer Robert Macfarlane calls "the literature of the leg"-include Immanuel Kant, Henry David Thoreau, Bruce Chatwin and Patrick Leigh Fermor.

title: Children's Books: Inside a Pharaoh's Tomb, Beneath a Troll's Bridge
summary: Tales from Ancient Egypt and present-day Pittsburgh-and more.. 'It was said . . . the boy king's tomb was cursed. In an underground burial chamber, in the flickering shadows made by their oil lamps, high priests had carried out ancient, mysterious rituals. As specified by The Book of the Dead, they had summoned protective demons and placed charms in the tomb's walls." Thus begins "The Curse of the Mummy", a work of nonfiction by Candace Fleming that will draw children's interest with a sense of lurid promise and keep them reading with the true story of the 1922 discovery of the long-lost tomb of Tutankhamun.

title: 'Balanchine's Apprentice' Review: Memories of the Master
summary: It was an electrifying period in New York City Ballet history, with Violette Verdy, Suzanne Farrell and Allegra Kent in the company.. I still have the program: Jan. 6, 1962-my first encounter with the New York City Ballet. It began with George Balanchine's single-act version of "Swan Lake," with Violette Verdy as the Swan Queen. (Even her name seemed out of a fairy tale.) I'd seen Verdy on television, but in person she was even more enchanting, more poignant. One of the swans was a radiant young Suzanne Farrell, on the verge of becoming Balanchine's supreme ballerina. This familiar classic was followed by the startlingly modern "Agon"-Balanchine's final, intimate collaboration with his friend and mentor Igor Stravinsky-which featured another legendary line-up, including Melissa Hayden and Edward Villella, with a knotty pas de deux by Allegra Kent and Arthur Mitchell, as harrowing as it was sexy. For me, this was a new way of seeing music. I had never been so mesmerized-or upended-by a performance.

title: Fran Drescher Wins Presidency of SAG-AFTRA
summary: A newcomer to union politics, Ms. Drescher beat actor Matthew Modine. Former sitcom star Fran Drescher defeated actor Matthew Modine in a close race to become president of SAG-AFTRA, the powerful Hollywood union that represents performers in contract negotiations with movie and television production companies.

summary: Texas Heartbeat Act, or SB 8, would ban most abortions in the state after about six weeks of pregnancy, with no exceptions for rape or incest. Here's a look at what the law does, and what's next for the legal controversy surrounding the new Texas rules and similar proposals being considered by state legislatures around the country.

title: A Farewell to Nation-Building
summary: Resume Subscription. In his Farewell Address of 1796, George Washington warned about the perils of foreign alliances, urging his young country to avoid entanglements abroad. More than a century later, his successor Theodore Roosevelt advocated a very different course, asserting that the U.S. should use its military power not only to defend its interests but to reshape the world in its image. Ever since, U.S. foreign policy has steered between these poles of isolation and intervention. Through the long years of the Cold War, the collapse of the Soviet Union and the fight against Islamist terrorism, the interventionist impulse has largely dominated.

title: Inventor Found a Way to Keep Trouser Creases Sharp
summary: Peter Corby, who has died at age 97, produced a device to prevent 'baggy knees syndrome'. After serving in Britain's Royal Air Force during World War II, Peter Corby went to work for his father in a business making valet stands, wooden frames used to stow a suit coat, necktie and trousers overnight. The trouble for business travelers was that they lacked a Jeeves or other valet to make sure the trousers retained a sharp crease.

title: Europe Eyes Afghanistan Presence as It Steps Up Talks With Taliban
summary: EU wants to link some form of political recognition for the Taliban to goals on terrorism and human rights. summary: Investors who no longer fear their bets could explode are seeking out risks they don't have to take. Bull markets give, and they take away.

summary: Some 40 million Americans have put at least part of their retirement money in these funds. And yet many investors are still in the dark about them.. For investors who want a "set it and forget it" retirement account, target-date funds have been the go-to solution.

title: Entrepreneur Used 'Peace Dress' Profits to Fund Political Causes
summary: Alvin Duskin, who has died at age 90, crusaded against skyscrapers and supported alternative energy sources. Alvin Duskin opened a store in San Francisco to sell sweaters in the mid-1960s. At the suggestion of a customer, he added 10 inches or so of length to the sweaters and turned them into snug minidresses. When he introduced an acrylic knit dress decorated with rows of peace signs in 1967, he had a hot-selling fashion item, soon dubbed the "peace dress."

title: Japan's Next Leader Set to Intensify Hawkish China Stance
summary: Two former foreign ministers are likely front-runners in race to succeed Yoshihide Suga. TOKYO-In the wake of Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's decision to quit, Japanese lawmakers prepared to select a leader who is likely to double down on a hawkish approach to China.

title: Martha's Vineyard in the Fall: An Insider's Guide
summary: Four discriminating locals share their favorite hotels, restaurants, autumn festivals and secret beaches on the Massachusetts island. WELL LOVED AS A summer colony for its inviting small towns and miles of tidal shoreline, this triangular island off the coast of Cape Cod also calls to visitors in the fall. The focus shifts from celebrity parties and Grace Church lobster rolls to the natural beauty of its well-tended farms, lush woodlands, ponds and beaches. Year-rounders insist the ocean is warmer, and events like the Striped Bass & Bluefish Derby and Oysterfest engage locals and outsiders alike; farm tours, film festivals and gallery hopping proceed at a leisurely pace. Lately, island history is getting renewed attention, from the refurbishing of Alley's General Store, the area's oldest retail business (1858) to interest in the Wampanoag people, the island's original inhabitants, who called the Vineyard "Noepe" or "land amid waters." Here, locals share secret beaches, favorite outdoor events, and fishing charters that come with satisfyingly tall tales.

title: Democrats Weigh $3.5 Trillion Agenda-and How Much Should Be Paid For
summary: Tax increases on corporations and capital gains find Democratic resistance, as party assembles fast-moving bill. WASHINGTON-Democrats seeking to pass their $3.5 trillion healthcare, education and climate legislation are wrestling over the amount they should pay with tax increases and other policy changes-and what should be funded with deficit spending.

title: Minneapolis Vote on Police Department Puts Democrats on Edge
summary: November initiative to replace police department with public safety agency could provide Republicans fodder for 2022 elections. SAVAGE, Minn-Residents in this Minneapolis suburb won't get to vote on a ballot question in November that seeks to eliminate Minnesota's largest police department, but some say the issue may influence their votes in next year's midterm elections.

summary: Schools hope the blended majors will make students more comfortable staying in nonbusiness disciplines. When Adam Johs was a student at the University of Iowa, he knew he wanted to eventually start a business. But he also knew he didn't want to take the management courses and other requirements in a traditional business-school curriculum.

title: Oregon's Covid-19 Wave Is at Its Worst Despite High Vaccination Rate
summary: Gaps in vaccination between urban and rural communities have led to overwhelming number of hospitalizations in the state. MEDFORD, Ore.-When the Covid-19 vaccines came out, Kelsea Robinson, manager of the intensive care unit at Asante Rogue Regional Medical Center in southern Oregon, said she thought the worst was finally behind her.

title: The Assistant Coach Who Became an Accidental SEC Starting Quarterback
summary: South Carolina graduate assistant Zeb Noland thought his playing days were over. Injuries and the pandemic have given him a second chance in the Southeastern Conference.. Zeb Noland thought his playing days were over. After five collegiate seasons, one redshirt year, two schools and one crushing loss in the Football Championship Subdivision tournament quarterfinals in May, the quarterback was ready to trade his pads for a coaching whistle. Within weeks he was working as a graduate assistant at South Carolina.

title: Airlines Are Flying Again, but People Aren't Giving Up Private Jets
summary: Private-aviation services are running at full tilt even as commercial flights come back. Private jets turn out to be a difficult habit to kick.

title: China's SMIC to Build Chip Production Line in Shanghai
summary: Chip maker will team up with government to build the facility amid a global shortage. TAIPEI-Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp., China's largest chip maker, said it is teaming up with the Shanghai government to build an $8.87 billion chip production line in the city, furthering China's ambitions for semiconductor self-sufficiency in the middle of a global chip shortage.

title: Mexico's President Revamps Welfare, Handing Out Cash to Millions
summary: Overhaul leaves some of the poorest households with limited healthcare access and reduced aid for fighting childhood malnutrition. President Andrés Manuel López Obrador has drastically revamped Mexico's welfare system-distributing more money to more people. But development experts say the new programs overlook some of the country's neediest families.

title: Chinese Essayist Revives Worries About a New Cultural Revolution
summary: The essay, hailing Beijing's regulatory campaigns as a 'profound revolution,' prompted a rebuttal from a leading nationalist. HONG KONG-A pair of dueling essays from Chinese commentators on the Communist Party's regulatory crackdown on some business sectors have sparked a broader public discussion about the direction of the country and whether it is heading toward turbulence not seen since the Cultural Revolution.

title: Editor in Chief Kristina O'Neill on WSJ. Magazine's Women's Fashion Issue
summary: In WSJ.'s Fall 2021 issue, a look at the aspirations of poet Amanda Gorman, the success of Zara's Marta Ortega Pérez and the allure of Indonesia.. Leadership doesn't necessarily mean following convention or adhering to a formula. That's one of the things Marta Ortega Pérez learned from her father, Amancio Ortega, the reclusive founder of the multibillion-dollar fashion behemoth Zara. Like her father-who still comes to the office nearly every day at age 85-Ortega Pérez sits at a shared workspace among fellow employees at Zara. Although she does not have an official title, our profile makes clear she's become an essential part of the branding and style setting that has made the company a standout among its competitors by being so nimble and responsive to shifts in consumer tastes.

title: 12 Dressy Ways to Keep Summer Going
summary: Mark a welcome return to glamour with sequins, embroidery, embellishment and bright colors, cut in ladylike silhouettes that recall the sirens of yesteryear.. It's all about the journey, not the destination, so treat an end-of-summer trip like the main event by choosing pieces that shimmer as brightly as the sea. Shot by Nadine Ijewere in the romantic seaside town of Torquay on the southeast coast of England, model Shivaruby sports vintage-inspired glamour styled by Kate Phelan. Sequined dresses from Bottega Veneta and Prada gain a graceful strength from monochrome green or black, while a rainbow skirt and gloves by Gucci show a playful side. For a more subdued shine that still exudes boldness, an intricately beaded set from Saint Laurent by Anthony Vaccarello and a metal crystal mesh Versace ensemble also catch the sun's rays in organic patterns. Standout embellishments on a statuesque Louis Vuitton dress and a crystal bodysuit from Dolce & Gabbana break through the clouds.

title: What Interviewing Amanda Gorman Is Really Like
summary: The contributors to WSJ.'s Fall 2021 issue, including writer Clover Hope on her profile of poet Amanda Gorman.. When writer Clover Hope interviewed Amanda Gorman for this issue's cover story, she found the poet to be "sharp, cerebral and intentional." Hope adds: "Almost every sentence she speaks could be framed, which is a very special gift." Going into their interview, she wondered how Gorman was navigating her newfound fame. "There's tension whenever someone is christened as a new voice, and I wanted to explore that," Hope says. Photographer Cass Bird captured Gorman, styled by Jason Bolden, at the Stahl House, a midcentury Los Angeles landmark designed by architect Pierre Koenig. "The location was the other character: simple but bold," says Bolden, who works with Gorman frequently. "This helped me lean into simple yet strong frocks." On set, "the energy was vibrant and fun," Bolden remembers. "Amanda laughed most of the time when she wasn't being the DJ!"

title: Chinese Stocks Need Better Rules, Not a New Exchange
summary: A new small-business-focused stock exchange in Beijing may be intended to soothe the worries of entrepreneurs. It isn't clear it will do much to help, however.. A new Chinese stock exchange will do little to address the problems in China's financial system.

summary: Research suggests there are certain rules to follow. Among them: Don't be too cute.. There is so much to do before you start your own company. You have to develop a business plan. You have to find financing. Oh, and you have to give it a name.

summary: Supply chain disruptions have been a long-running thread for apparel sellers. The latest snag-factory shutdowns in Vietnam-comes as retailers stock up for the holiday season.. Shoppers should brace for an odd and expensive holiday season.

summary: Microsoft, other companies use difficult-to-measure information about suppliers and customers to reach emissions totals. Microsoft Corp. has halved its greenhouse-gas emissions-with a wave of a calculator.

title: Counting Little Kids Is a Big Challenge for the U.S. Census
summary: Demographers suspect many young children are missed in the country's decennial population tally. The omissions carry costs.. For decades, little kids have given the U.S. Census Bureau the slip.

summary: Resume Subscription. Soaring Covid-19 caseloads are endangering patients who need urgent medical care at some overwhelmed hospitals, according to doctors, nurses and industry executives in states where the virus has filled beds at or near record numbers.

title: Ida, Wildfires Prod Congress on Infrastructure Resiliency
summary: Storm battered Louisiana, causing flooding and leaving hundreds of thousands without electricity. HURRICANE IDA AND WESTERN WILDFIRES are putting pressure on lawmakers to approve funds for infrastructure resiliency projects. While business groups and Republican senators who supported the bipartisan infrastructure deal, which includes $50 billion for resiliency projects and another $65 billion to harden the electrical grid, push for its swift passage, dozens of House Democrats are pressing leadership to include more resiliency programs in the separate Democrats-only budget reconciliation package.

title: Chip Shortage Curtails Heavy-Duty Truck Production
summary: The semiconductor shortfall is cascading into truck factories, cutting into output as demand for big rigs grows. The semiconductor shortage is short-circuiting heavy-duty truck production as supply-chain disruptions hamper efforts to meet robust demand for new big rigs.

title: Derby's Take: August Jobs Data Looms Large in Fed Taper Call
summary: Job market's performance is now the make or break factor in determining when a pullback in asset buying will kick off. Federal Reserve officials say that when they look at the data that drives their policy decisions, they focus on the trend rather than any one month's number.

title: Car Buyers Face Bleak Prospects This Labor Day Weekend
summary: The holiday is historically one of the auto industry's biggest sales events, but dealers have very little inventory to sell this year. The U.S. auto industry is heading into one of its biggest selling weekends of the year with dealership lots stripped bare of inventory and some buyers having to drive great distances to secure a new ride.

title: Japan's Next Prime Minister: Who Are the Candidates to Succeed Yoshihide Suga?
summary: Former Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida is among those who have a shot at winning the vote to lead the ruling Liberal Democratic Party. Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga has ended his bid for re-election as leader of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party and is expected to step down as prime minister after the party selects a new leader. Traditionally the head of the party that controls Parliament concurrently serves as prime minister.

title: New Zealand Police Kill Terror Suspect After Mall Stabbings
summary: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern identifies attacker as a Sri Lankan man who had been under surveillance for his extremist views. WELLINGTON, New Zealand-Police shot and killed a suspected Islamist terrorist who stabbed several people in a supermarket in New Zealand's largest city on Friday.

title: Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga to Step Down
summary: His decision, coming after a year in the top job, brings political instability back in U.S. ally. TOKYO-Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga said he won't seek re-election as ruling-party leader, effectively ending his term after just a year and bringing back political instability in one of Washington's most important allies.

title: Sugar Prices Soar After Brazil Cold Snap
summary: Prices are likely to stay elevated for several months, analysts say. Sugar prices shot to four-year highs after a frost in Brazil cut the size of the cane crop in the world's biggest producer, and hedge funds are adding to the market's momentum.

title: Northeast States Press Recovery Efforts After Deadly Storm
summary: Posttropical cyclone drops more than 3 inches of rain in an hour in New York City. States in the Northeast began recovery efforts Thursday after the remnants of Hurricane Ida unleashed record-breaking rainfalls, flash floods and tornadoes in a powerful burst that blindsided some in the region and killed at least 45 people.

title: CBO Expects $200 Billion From IRS Boost, Below Biden Targets
summary: Democrats are counting on money from tougher tax enforcement to fund their agenda. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration's proposed $80 billion boost for the Internal Revenue Service's budget would yield $200 billion in new revenue over a decade, according to a Congressional Budget Office estimate released Thursday. That figure demonstrates the significant potential from ramping up tax enforcement but is also more than 36% below the administration's own estimate.
